ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Q9: I was happy to go to NRDC and talk to people there, but it seemed like we could have gained just as much by talking to one of those people for a longer time at Yale. I just didn't see the point really of spending 5 hours of travel time to sit in a conference room all day. just the same, i learned a lot, but might have learned more in a more concentrated format.

Kit and Hayley did an excellent job. I really appreciated how responsive Kit was to questions.It seemed like the course was a little backloaded. I know that the field trip was scheduled for when people in the class said that they could attend, so that's no fault of Kit's but having the Moot Court and the climate negotiations during consecutive weeks was challenging. Both of those exercises were great.

Class was great - well run, purposeful and very useful. My only comment was that the field trip ended up being quite similar to what we get everyday (and hence shouldn't travel for): namely, lectures in a closed room. What would have been much more interesting and exciting would be if we had gotten to meet with NRDC employees in small groups (3:1) to talk about their jobs, how they got there, what they are doing, how it is to work at NRDC. As it was, I don't think I would have chosen to go on the field trip if I had known that we were just getting lectures in a conference room (not worth the full day away from being able to do work). Still, it was nice to meet some people at NRDC and see the building.
Your experience depends on your fit with the client project and your team.

Field trips/lab activities were well designed and ran smoothly. Field trips were included in this course in two ways. First, there was a field trip to NRDC. This was well organized and efficiently executed, but the content was a little disappoint. I would suggest that in future years, rather than an all day seminar with lectures and discussions for the whole class together, breaking up into groups of 3-4 and meeting one on one with NRDC staff would be better. I'm sure there's a way for this to be arranged that would take the same time commitment (or perhaps less) from NRDC staff. Perhaps students could identify NRDC staff working on projects that interest them and then spend 30 mins together. Second, I spent two weeks at the UNFCCC conference in South Africa working with my client. This was a once in a lifetime learning experience and something that is an incredibly valuable part of my graduate program. I learned so much about how international environmental laws are negotiated and implemented.
This was an excellent course. It was an opportunity for students to get hands-on experience in a real world project and work closely with a client organization.
I think the trip to NRDC would have been more useful if it was more interactive. Maybe we could have had small group time with the speakers to hear more about their work and career paths.
Question 9: Great Field trip, well planned and very productive. Visiting the NRDC building in NYC is a great addition to the course both fun and extremely educational. Thank you!
working for a real client. this was the reason to take the class. the other stuff was fun exercises, but not really related to the consulting work.

The client projects available for us to work on were all incredible. They were all substantive, interesting projects for great organizations that allowed us to make real, significant contributions. I was really impressed with the projects from watching everyones presentation at the end, and want to thank Kit for doing the work to put the list together!
The Moot Court and climate negotiations were valuable.The work with our client was very meaningful.I liked having both check ins and the independence we had.
The projects of course. Big diversity and lots of valuable work experience.
The challenge of organizing an approach to a fairly wide-open client objective was a worthwhile experience
trip to UNFCCC in South Africa. environmental law bootcamp. guest speakers. moot court.
I had the opportunity to work on a project of interest to me, and that will prepare me for my future career.
Getting to work with clients, also the classroom activities were really helpful.

Working with a client. The experience of working with a client was invaluable! We all learned so much about real world applications to environmental law, policy, and advocacy through client interaction and feedback.The Moot court and climate change negotiations exercises were also great!

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: nothing. it was fine.

I actually would have liked to have more class time to tackle broad legal and environmental issues relevant for both law and FES students. The campaign class was fun and the oral argument exercise was valuable. More activities would have been great.
I explained above (just the backloading).
very little, see suggestions for NRDC field trip
N/A
The quality of your experience will depend on the responsiveness of your client, which really varied between groups.
maybe Lecture structure, although this semester seemed a bit hectic for the instructor.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: they were great.
Excellent. The instructor was very helpful in guiding the project, she was responsive to emails, and always provided thoughtful, substantive comments in a timely fashion.
Excellent.
Instructor was very good at drawing out issues which the team was having with the project and helping to keep the team focused on moving forward. Available and responsive at meetings and by email.
Very available, high quality
The professor and TA were always available and responded to questions in a timely fashion. They provided advice on how to engage with our clients, and provided excellent feedback on final projects.
Both Kit and Hayley were always available either during the biweekly meetings or through email. They both answered questions quickly and work hard to clarify any issue.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: i wanted to work on a real-life project with a real-life client. we are going to have to do this when we leave this school, so it was nice to give it a try in a safe space like a class.
As an FES student, I am making efforts to take courses cross-listed with other schools in order to broaden my perspective, meet other Yale students, and get outside of Kroon hall.
I am a FES student and was very interested in my client's project.

We had a project which involved analyzing part of a complex regulatory scheme, which was of course riddled with pitfalls. Making responsible recommendations meant looking at the whole system so that changes to parts of it could be consistent with a concept of a better-integrated whole. So this was a practical exercise in the work I was most interested in at FES.

This course fits very well into my program. I have been able to use the foundation I have gained in environmental law as well as knowledge from previous work experience. I am very thankful to have the opportunity to work on projects that I feel I can both contribute to and learn a great deal from.

Working with the NRDC as a client allowed me to a have a great introduction to the Rio+20 topic and advocacy initiatives. Considering that I would like my master research to be focused on the Rio conference this experience was amazing.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: SKILLZ
I was interested in taking a project-based course that involved working with a client so that my work would have real world applications.
I was totally interested in the project and am interested in Environmental Law.
To experience law-based environmental advocacy, get more environmental policy experience, and evaluate whether I might want to go to law school.
Reason given in question above
I wanted to learn about environmental law and I learn better in project based courses than in lecture based courses. Perfect combo!
I had a great experience taking the course in the past and wanted to explore another project.
Client work.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: exceeded them.

I expected to gain new skills related to legal research that I did not previously possess, like legal writing, legal research, knowing how to use the Blue Book and do legal citations, etc. Unfortunately, this did not really happen because my project did not need these things, and because these topics werent covered in great depth during class.
Yes.
Yes
yes, definitely.

Doing something useful for the client was as difficult, or more, than I expected. Working as a team was surprisingly difficult. So it surpassed my expectations of difficulty, but challenge was the experience I signed on for.....
YES!!
Yes, and more.
Yes, though it was frustrating at times when our client was not responsive and unavailable. Luckily Kit and the TA helped us to deal with this challenge.
YES!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: more than.
Yes, I had the opportunity to learn a lot about a new issue outside my traditional area of focus, which proved to be a fascinating and fruitful undertaking. I am really, really glad I did this.
No. I got more!
Yes
Yes. I havent answered all my questions but I am very glad that I took the course.
Answer is in question above
YES!! and more!
Yes with the client area however I hoped we would learn more about environmental law in class following the week's readings.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: my partner was living in NYC, so i never really got to work with him in person. this was extremely challenging at times, and made for the feeling of really working alone. However, i think doing the project in groups is a good idea, and would have probably been a lot easier to deal with had my partner lived in the same state as me.

The main advantage was that my group partner possessed skills I did not, so our skill set balanced well. She also provided good, critical feedback on my work products and I did the same for her. The disadvantage was that we were both new to the issue and so we had to duplicate a lot of each others work by reading the same documents to bring ourselves up to speed.
Working in a group was vey helpful.
My team was dysfunctional as a group. Those of us who put the required effort in to the project had to make it work individually. Which was also a useful experience.
In working with our client, it was helpful to have teammates with whom to discuss ideas before presenting them to the client.
Advantages:Group members provided helpful feedback on written work. It was great to brainstorm ideas together. I think we did a great job at designating tasksDisadvantages: N/A
Nice to work on these bigger projects with a team - it would be great if there was a way to ensure law students were on teams that involved law topics.
Advantages: they can be motivating and very helpful with coordinating communication with the client.Disadvantages: sometimes hard to coordinate schedules

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: be patient with your client.

We interviewed several experts during the course of doing the research for our project, and it helped immensely in saving time and helping us hone in on the most relevant issues. I recommend that other groups do the same when possible.
Start working right away! Get as much done early on as you can.

You don't necessarily get the project of your first choice, and you don't necessarily pick your team members, and the work for the client doesn't necessarily go the way you'd like it to, but if you try, you'll probably get an experience you need out of it. The professor recognizes this and advises us of such possibilities up front; this is part of professional work.
Have fun!!!!!
Work out a feasible work plan with clients and be clear about deliverables early on.
Communicate often with your client, ask questions, stay on top of your research.
